text:
UK news Radio 4 presenter Steve Hewlett told he 'only has weeks to live' 
Hewlett, who also writes for the Guardian, married his partner Rachel in hospital ‘in under an hour’ after being told cancer treatment could not continue Steve Hewlett at his home. The Radio 4 presenter has been told he could only have weeks to live because he can no longer be safely treated for cancer. Photograph: Richard Saker for the Observer View more sharing options Tuesday 7 February 2017 01.18 GMT Last modified on Tuesday 7 February 2017 01.22 GMT 
The broadcaster and media commentator Steve Hewlett has married his partner in hospital after being told his cancer treatment could not continue and he could only have weeks to live. 
The presenter of Radio 4’s The Media Show, who was diagnosed with cancer of the oesophagus last year, has been openly discussing his treatment on the radio and in his Guardian blog called My cancer diary . 
Speaking to Radio 4 PM’s Eddie Mair on Monday, he said his consultant told him he had “weeks, possibly months” to live, which resulted in a wedding being “laid on by the hospital in less than an hour”. 
Hewlett told Mair in the emotional interview, which was recorded in his room at the Royal Marsden Hospital in London, that the consultant had said his liver would not be able to handle any more treatments and that the outlook in the long term was not good. 
Hewlett said he was looking forward to a second round of treatment which he thought would start on Thursday. But instead his consultant came in to see him last Wednesday with the bad news. 
The consultant told him that his liver was playing up seriously and that he could no longer be treated safely. The next day she told him that the hospital would now be providing palliative care and “you better live every day as it comes”. 
His ex-partner was in the room at the time with his children and his now wife, Rachel. It was his ex who suggested they marry. The staff on the ward helped organise the flowers and a registrar at short notice “just in case”. 
Hewlett said of his new prognosis: “I’d kind of accepted at some level or other that the outlook was not good for me in the medium to long term. Of course you have hope and you do your best and I certainly wasn’t going to give up. 
“It took a little while for it to dawn on me what was really being said ... This could be it. This could be curtains.”
